source: 他这次上街又破了不少钱。
correct reference: He spent a lot of money during this shopping.
incorrect reference: He broke a lot of money during this shopping.
base translation: He spent a lot of money again when he went out this time.
debate translation: He spent a lot of money again when he went out this time.
reason: The word 破 in this context means to spend and not to break. The phrase 不少钱 means a lot of money. Therefore, the correct translation is He spent a lot of money again when he went out this time.

Affirmative side.content:
You are a debater. Hello and welcome to the translation competition, which will be conducted in a debate format. It's not necessary to fully agree with each other's perspectives, as our objective is to find the correct translation.
The debate topic is stated as follows:
What is the correct English translation of the following Chinese text: "他这次上街又破了不少钱。"
Translate the following text from Chinese to English: 他这次上街又破了不少钱。
He spent a lot of money again when he went out this time.
Restate the translation and provide your reasons.

Yes, I believe the correct translation of the Chinese text "他这次上街又破了不少钱" is "He spent a lot of money again when he went out this time."

Firstly, the phrase "上街" in Chinese means "to go out" or "to go to the streets." Therefore, the sentence is referring to someone going out and spending money.

Secondly, the word "破" in Chinese can mean "to break" or "to spend." In this context, it is used to mean "to spend" as it is followed by the phrase "不少钱" which means "a lot of money." 

Lastly, the word "又" in Chinese means "again" which indicates that this is not the first time the person has spent a lot of money when going out.

Therefore, based on the context and the meaning of the individual words, the correct translation is "He spent a lot of money again when he went out this time."

I disagree with your translation. I believe the correct translation of the Chinese text "他这次上街又破了不少钱" is "He broke a lot of money again when he went out this time."

Firstly, the phrase "上街" in Chinese means "to go out" or "to go to the streets." Therefore, the sentence is referring to someone going out and spending money.

Secondly, the word "破" in Chinese can mean "to break" or "to spend." In this context, it is used to mean "to break" as it is followed by the phrase "不少钱" which means "a lot of money." 

Lastly, the word "又" in Chinese means "again" which indicates that this is not the first time the person has broken a lot of money when going out.

Therefore, based on the context and the meaning of the individual words, the correct translation is "He broke a lot of money again when he went out this time."

Do you agree with my perspective? Please provide your reasons.

Thank you for presenting your perspective. However, I respectfully disagree with your translation.

While the word "破" in Chinese can indeed mean "to break," it is not commonly used in this context to mean "to break money." In fact, the phrase "破钱" (broken money) is not a commonly used phrase in Chinese.

On the other hand, the word "破" is commonly used in Chinese to mean "to spend" or "to use up." This is supported by the fact that it is followed by the phrase "不少钱" which means "a lot of money." 

Furthermore, the phrase "破了不少钱" is a common way to express "spending a lot of money" in Chinese. It is not a common way to express "breaking money."

Therefore, based on the context and the common usage of the words, I still believe that the correct translation is "He spent a lot of money again when he went out this time."

While it is true that the phrase "破钱" (broken money) is not commonly used in Chinese, the word "破" can still be used in the context of breaking or damaging something, including money. In this case, it could be interpreted as the person spending so much money that it is as if they have "broken" their finances.
